reviewText: Supernatural suspense abounds in this creeper, full of mystery, murder, and revenge from beyond the grave. INTO THE MIRROR is the fantastic, South Korean source material for the american remake (MIRRORS). A great ghost story w/ many twists and a wonderfully bleak finale! Well worth owning...
Title: N/A

reviewText: I almost turned this movie off half way through the first time I watched it. Its not the scariest film you'll ever watch, the ghosts are sneaky but the characters seem to have a hard time figuring out theyre ghost, even though you see them a lot. I dont want to give away anything, but the ending was what made me love this movie and watch it again. I had this moment where everything about the movie just became cool.

reviewText: Into the Mirror (Sung-ho Kim, 2003)Made into Mirrors, one of the more surprisingly well-handled American remakes of Asian horror movies. So when I saw that, it was pretty much a given I'd eventually get round to renting the movie upon which it is based and compare the two. While there is one major change (which it's easy to rationalize along cultural lines), the American remake is surprisingly faithful to the Korean original.Yeong-min (Lady Vengeance's Ji-tae Yu) is an ex-cop whose life is dragging along until his uncle gets him a job guarding a burnt-out department store that's in the process of being renovated. There have been some murders on the property recently, all having to do with mirrors, and Yeong-min's old departmental rival, Hyeon-su (Sorum's Myeong-min Kim), is heading up the investigation. The two of them are generally thinking along the same lines until a new player enters the game: Ji-hyeun Lee (Don't Look Back's Hye-na Kim), the twin sister of a woman who is believed to have died in the fire that burned the department store to the ground. Ji-hyeun believes her sister isn't dead, that she's tapped in the department store's mirrors. Yeong-min ends up believing her, while Hyeon-su believes she's the killer, and soon the mystery spirals out of control.Not bad; if you've seen a few Asian horror films form the last decade, you can probably list the film's strengths and weaknesses without actually having seen it. And it plays perfectly to type here, giving you a good, solid mystery/horror flick without introducing anything special to the genre. (The main difference between the American and Korean versions, BTW, comes in the climax; you'll know it when you see it.) On the up side, if you're looking for a random Asian horror film and haven't seen this one yet, it's well worth a rental. On the downside, if you're looking for something that transcends the bounds of the genre, this ain't it. ***
Title: N/A

reviewText: Inventive and original and stunningly shot, this chiller is less in your face than you might expect from a Tartan Extreme (UK) release and is as much a who done it as a what done it.Ex-cop turned store detective investigates a series of murders in the soon to open shop. Investigations hinge on deaths in a mysterious fire months previously. Are the murders revenge for those deaths because the company is witholding compensation? Is it actually the ghosts of the dead haunting the store?Throw in some dodgy share dealing, the ex-cop with a history and a quite unexpected and not a little bit chilling final twist and it all adds up to a supremely satisfying experience that withstands repeated viewing.
summary: Class chiller thriller that's less horrific than expected.
Title: N/A
